intro: Trigonella podlechii, commonly known as the Persian fenugreek, is a herbaceous annual plant native to the Mediterranean region and parts of Central Asia. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, characterized by its pod-like fruits and nitrogen-fixing abilities. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm, with trifoliate leaves and small yellow flowers. Its seeds are harvested for their medicinal and culinary uses, containing compounds like saponins and alkaloids. Trigonella podlechii thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in disturbed or arid environments.
